contentrichtext.text: {{History of Japan|Shoso-in.jpg| Image explanation = [[Shōsōin]]}} {{nihongo|'''Enpō'''|延宝}}, also '''Empo''', was a {{nihongo|[[Japanese era name]]|年号,|''nengō'',|lit. "year name"}} after ''[[Kanbun (era)|Kanbun]]'' and before ''[[Tenna]].'' This period spanned the years from September 1673 to September 1681.<ref>Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric ''et al.'' (2005). "Empo" in {{Google books|p2QnPijAEmEC|''Japan encyclopedia'', p. 176.|page=176.}}</ref> The reigning emperor was {{nihongo|[[Emperor Reigen of Japan|Reigen]]''-tennō''|霊元天皇}}.<ref>Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). [http://books.google.com/books?id=Cg8oAAAAMAAJ&printsec=titlepage&dq=editions:OCLC63259938#PRA1-PA414,M1 ''Annales des empereurs du japon'', pp. 414-415.]</ref> ==Change of era== * '''1673''' {{nihongo|''Enpō gannen''|延宝元年}}: The new era of ''Enpō'' (meaning "Prolonged Wealth") was created to mark a number of disasters including a great fire in [[Kyoto|Kyōto]]. The previous era ended and a new one commenced in ''Kanbun'' 14, on the ninth day of the 13th month. ==Events of the ''Enpō'' era== * '''1673''' (''Enpō 1''): There was a great fire in [[Heian-kyō]].<ref name="t414">Titsingh, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Cg8oAAAAMAAJ&printsec=titlepage&dq=editions:OCLC63259938#PRA1-PA414,M1 p. 414.]</ref> * '''1673''' (''Enpō 1''): The foundations for [[Mitsui]] financial success began with the opening of a dry good store in [[Edo]].<ref>Hall, John Whitney. (1970). ''Japan: From Prehistory to Modern Times'', p. 209.</ref> * '''May 10, 1674''' (''Enpō 2, 5th day of the 4th month'')<!-- NengoCalc 延宝二年四月五日 -->: [[Ingen Ryuki]], founder of the [[Ōbaku (school of Buddhism)|Ōbaku sect]] of Japanese Zen Buddhism, died at [[Mampuku-ji]], a Buddhist temple which Ingen had founded at [[Uji, Kyoto|Uji]], near Heian-kyō.<ref name="t414"/> * '''1675''' (''Enpō 3''): A devastating fire burned Heian-kyō.<ref name="t414"/> * '''1675''' (''Enpō 3''): The [[Bonin Islands]] (''Ogasawara'' Islands) are explored by shogunate expedition, following up "discovery" of the islands by the Japanese when a ship bound for Edo from Kyūshū is blown off course by a storm in ''[[Kanbun (era)|Kanbun]]'' 10. The islands are claimed as a territory of Japan.<ref>Tanaka, Hiroyuki. (1993). "The Ogasawara Islands in Tokugawa Japan", ''Kaiji Shi Kenkyuu (Journal of the Maritime History)''.</ref> * '''April 7, 1680''' (''Enpō 8, 8th day of the 3rd month)<!-- NengoCalc 延宝八年三月八日 --> : [[Tokugawa Ietsuna]], the 4th shogun of the [[Tokugawa shogunate|Edo bakufu]] died; and his named successor, [[Tokugawa Tsunayoshi]], was ready to take his place as the 5th Tokugawa shogun.<ref name="t414"/> ==Notes== {{reflist|1}} ==References== * [[John Whitney Hall|Hall, John Whitney]].
